title: Help needed troubleshooting automatic junk filter
content:
I've been using Thunderbird for years and love it! I have multiple email addresses, but I'm having problems for a good year or so with one of my gmail accounts that gets a lot of junk mail. Gmail filters suspected junk mail and places it in a folder called spam. I know how to use webmail and mark an email as not spam. I also know how to setup a filter that says, Never send to spam. Despite taking these steps, I have messages that within a minute of marking "not spam", end up moving right back to the spam folder. I've been trying everything I can think of and then I found under settings that I could uncheck Show in IMAP for the Spam folder and it wouldn't appear in Thunderbird. <see image attached> Once I did that, I could mark a message as "not spam" or just move back to my inbox through webmail and it will now stay in the inbox. But that means I can't view the spam folder through Thunderbird, which isn't ideal.

So I need help determining what is causing the emails to move from the Inbox to Spam when IMAP is turned on for the Spam folder and I open Thunderbird so that I can hopefully stop Thunderbird from moving them. I've tried unchecking adaptive junk mail, SpamAssassin, and Move new junk messages. <see images attached>

What can I do and where can I look to determine what is causing the emails to move when Spam is turned on in IMAP?

Thanks in advance for your help, Elspeth Coats

title: A way to measure which senders and/or subjects are consuming the most mailbox space (in gmail)
content:
I use Thunderbird with Gmail, and of course Gmail is complaining that I'm almost out of space.

I'm looking for a way to find the senders and/or subjects that consume the most space. I know there are some extensions that calculate statistics, but I'm not seeing "newsletter X is Y Megabytes total", or Here are your "senders (From: or Reply-to: etc.)" ranked from largest % of your mailbox to smallest.

I have something like 15+ years of email, and I know there's a bunch of newsletters that are no longer useful buried in there but it's not easy to find the biggest few and delete those.

My other desire is to be able to apply a 'delete this email in 7 days automatically' policy to some emails (Today's Deals!) unless I flag it somehow or remove the policy. Is there some mechanism in Thunderbird to accomplish this? TIA
